information_requirement: Is an adversary capturing user credentials via input manipulation? (PIR)

evidence.description: A non-standard or unapproved third-party keyboard application is installed on a managed mobile device.
evidence.nai: Corporate-issued and BYOD mobile devices with corporate access
evidence.action: Using MDM Application Inventory, create and maintain an allow-list of approved keyboard applications. Periodically scan all managed devices and alert on any installed keyboards not on this list. For any alerted device, analyze its recent network traffic in Zeek http.log, specifically looking for POST requests to unusual or newly-seen domains. Calculate the entropy of the URI or hostname to identify potential command-and-control (C2) or data exfiltration channels.

evidence.description: An application, whose core function does not justify it, is granted high-risk permissions, such as the ability to draw over other applications or to use accessibility services.
evidence.nai: Corporate-issued and BYOD mobile devices with corporate access
evidence.action: From MDM Application Permission Logs, establish a baseline of applications that legitimately require 'draw over other apps' or 'Accessibility Service' permissions. Use a scoring model to flag applications where these permissions are anomalous based on the app's store category and description. For flagged applications, analyze their network behavior in Zeek conn.log. Compare the daily outbound data volume (orig_bytes) for the host against its own 30-day rolling average and standard deviation. An alert should be triggered if the data volume exceeds a statistical threshold (e.g., 3 standard deviations above the mean) shortly after the suspicious application is launched.
